required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Carotid Artery Analysis During an LPEC Manoeuvre
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of the Left Paratracheal Compression of the Cervical Esophagus and the Sellick Manoeuvre on the Compressibility of the Carotid Artery and Its Possible Effects on the Vascular Flow

brief_summary.textblock: Verify in ultrasound the impact of a Sellick and LPEC manoeuvre in terms of compression of the carotid artery and decrease in vascular flow.

primary_outcome.measure: Compression of the carotid artery during an esophageal compression manoeuvre
primary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of 1 month
primary_outcome.description: Measurement of the diameter of the carotid artery in cross-section and longitudinal section

primary_outcome.measure: Vascular flow of the carotid artery during an esophageal compression manoeuvre
primary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of 1 month
primary_outcome.description: Measurement of systolic velocities in pulsed Doppler in the carotid artery

secondary_outcome.measure: Measurement of the force to be applied to compress the esophagus without compressing the carotid artery
secondary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of 1 month
secondary_outcome.description: use of a dynamometer to measure the force required to exert at the left paratracheal level

intervention.description: We will perform an ultrasound of the carotid artery and then apply a Sellick manoeuvre and a left paratracheal compression of the cervical esophagus respectively.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adults Volunteers
Exclusion Criteria:
- pregnant women
- people with carotid artery defects
- people with an anomaly in the oropharyngeal massif
